Detailed Description

Class to deal with leap seconds.

Member Function Documentation

static LeapSeconds* vrt::LeapSeconds::getDefaultInstance (  )  [static]

Gets the default instance.

This will return the instance previously set with setDefaultInstance(..); if no default instance has yet been set, the VRTConfig#getLeapSecondsFile() will be used as the default.

Returns:
An using the give file.

Referenced by vrt::TimeStamp::forNoradTime(), vrt::TimeStamp::forTime(), vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeIRIG(), vrt::TimeStamp::forTimeNORAD(), vrt::TimeStamp::forTimePOSIX(), vrt::TimeStamp::forTimePTP(), vrt::TimeStamp::getSystemTime(), and vrt::TimeStamp::parseTime().

static LeapSeconds* vrt::LeapSeconds::getInstance ( string  fname  )  [static]

Gets an instance with the given tai-utc.dat file.

On the first call to this method the file will be opened and read. Subsequent calls may either re-open the file or return the an existing open copy.

Parameters:
fname Name of the file to read from.
Returns:
An using the give file.

Referenced by setDefaultInstance().

double vrt::LeapSeconds::getLeapSeconds ( double  wsec,
double  fsec 
) const

Calculate and return the difference between TAI (International Atomic Time) and UTC (Universal Coordinated Time) for the given time.

Generally, this will be the number of leap seconds in effect at that time. Between 1961/01/01 and 1972/01/01 this was a sliding value with fractional offset; since 1972/01/01 this is an integral number of seconds.

The functionality of this method matches the m_get_leap_seconds(..) method in X-Midas's leap_seconds.cc class, but uses an optimized algorithm for the most common cases.

Parameters:
wsec The number of whole seconds in Midas time referenced to UTC.
fsec The number of fractional seconds (ignored after 1972/01/01).
Returns:
The difference between TAI and UTC (i.e. TAI - UTC) in seconds.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the date is before 1961/01/01.
int32_t vrt::LeapSeconds::getLeapSecondsPOSIX ( int64_t  posix  )  const

Gets the number of leap seconds elapsed prior to the given time.

Parameters:
posix Number of days elapsed since 1970/01/01 multiplied by 86400, plus the number of seconds in the current day.
Returns:
Leap seconds elapsed during prior to the given time.
Exceptions:
VRTException if the input time is before 1972/01/01. (Between 1970 and 1972, the number of leap seconds is non-integral.)
int32_t vrt::LeapSeconds::getLeapSecondsUTC ( int64_t  utc  )  const

Gets the number of leap seconds elapsed prior to the given time.

Parameters:
utc 1-second time tics since 1970/01/01.
Returns:
Leap seconds elapsed during prior to the given time.
Exceptions:
VRTException if the input time is before 1972/01/01. (Between 1970 and 1972, the number of leap seconds is not-integral.)
int32_t vrt::LeapSeconds::getMonth ( int32_t  year,
int64_t  utc 
) const

Internal use only: Gets month number based on UTC year (1970..N) and UTC time (from 1970).

In this form 'year' is technically redundant (since it can be computed from 'utc'), but it is here to skip that computation.

bool vrt::LeapSeconds::isLeapSecond ( int64_t  utc  )  const

Internal use only: Is the identified UTC time equal to an inserted leap second? That is, is the time equal to the 86401th second of the day (23:59:60)?

Parameters:
utc 1-second time tics since 1970/01/01.
Returns:
true if the time is 23:59:60, false otherwise.
Exceptions:
VRTException if the input time is before 1972/01/01.
static int32_t vrt::LeapSeconds::isLeapYear ( int32_t  year  )  [inline, static]

Internal Use Only: Indicates if the given year is a leap year.

The code for this method was copied from RFC 3339. 

    Source: Klyne, et.al. "RFC 3339 / Date and Time on the Internet: Timestamps."
            ITEF, July 2002. http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339 (Retrieved 2007-06-15)
Parameters:
year The year number.
Returns:
true if it is a leap year, false otherwise.
